entries: {@i "Oh, Dumosia, bathe them in light and clean their spirits!"}
Spell learned by the followers of Madre Cajsa, the Enlightened.
This spell requires {@status concentration} until the disc returns to the caster.

A disc of pure divine light (5 ft. long and 5 ft. wide) appears in your hand, which you throw in a 30 ft. straight line. Each creature in the discs path, including when it stops moving, must make a Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 2d6} radiant damage. The disc, after reaching 30 ft., stays spinning in the air until the end of your next turn. If a creature begins its turn in the same space of the disc, it takes an additional {@damage 2d6} radiant damage.
At the end of your next turn, the disc returns to you in a straight line, dealing another {@dice 2d6} of radiant damage to any creature in the line that fails the saving throw.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, each individual damage of the spell increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Flaming Punch
entries: {@i "The frail wizard was amazed by the flame, by its destructive power, and its blinding light. So he held it tightly, until it consumed his hand entirely."}
Spell learned by the old band of wizards that ventured into the Blazing Pit and perfected by Alfred, the Exiled.

You hold your hand back, channeling a magical blaze in it, releasing it afterwards with a powrful scorching punch on the target. Make a melee spell attack, on a hit, the target takes {@damage 2d8} fire damage and becomes {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d8} for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Minor Fireballs
entries: {@i "Fire consumes life, turning all into ash."}
Spell learned by the old band of wizards from the Kvarotz Mountain Range that ventured into the Blazing Pit.

You open both your hands and, after muttering a few ancient words, one small fireball appears above each of them, resulting in an explosion of flames after being thrown. They can be thrown at the same time or one at a time, in which case you can use a one handed weapon while still holding the last fireball. Each creature in a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on the point of impact must make a Dexterity saving throw. A target takes {@damage 2d6} fire damage for each fireball on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The fire spreads around corners. It ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.

components.m: a blazing magmatic rock and a cup of liquid sulfur

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage of both fireballs increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Slimefoot's Survey
entries: Raffwyn Capashen took notice of Slimefoot's attempts to be useful to the crew. The fungus would take a spyglass, watch over distant lands, and report all of his findings through fungal writings on the floor of the Weatherlight. Raffwyn was inspired by his colleague to create a spell that would make this process faster, and infallible. After a few months of working, Slimefoot's Survey was created in his honor, and was extensively used by the Weatherlight.

However, the spell rendered Slimefoot's job useless, and that made their fungal companion very sad. Shanna couldn't stand for it, and asked Raffwyn to pause the use of the spell until further notice. The man agreed, and while Slimefoot happily returned to his survey duties, the mage sent his discoveries to Tolarian universities, and whoever else in the world that wanted to listen and needed his knowledge.

Describe or name an object or a creature. You sense the direction to the objects or creatures' location, as long as it is within 1,000 feet of you, and you also know how many of it currently exist in the area of the spell. If they are in motion, you know the direction of their movement.

The spell can locate a specific object or creature known to you, as long as you have seen it up close—within 30 feet—at least once. Alternatively, the spell can locate all objects of a particular kind, such as a certain kind of apparel, jewelry, furniture, tool, or weapon, that exist in the area of the spell.

components.m: a spyglass

spell.name: Smoulderskin

entries: {@i To avenge for our fallen ones, Nature shows the face they think they wield to scowl at the fools who dare set fire to our home.}
entries.by: A druid from the Ashen Glades

entries: You touch a willing creature, it skin and flesh starts to show fiery cracks in it just as well as it starts to seem more like some sort of dark grey oak with spikes protruding everywhere and the target's AC is set to 10. The target also gains resistance to non-magical bludgeoning, slashing and piecing damage plus immunity to fire damage for the duration.

Every time the creature is attacked during the duration, they may use a reaction to have their fiery brambles lash out at whomever attacked them as long as they're within a 30-ft radius originating from the attacked creature, forcing them to do a Dexterity saving throw against your Spell Save DC, taking {@damage 3d6} fire damage, or half on a success.

components.m: a bramble from a burnt oak tree.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Sheoldred's Restoration
entries: You touch a willing creature. That creature will be warded from death, and if it becomes {@condition unconscious} by reaching 0 hit points, it will immediately recover half of its hit points and stand back up, as well as gain 2 points of {@condition exhaustion}. This spell can't return to life a creature that has died of old age, nor can it restore any missing body parts.

m.text: black diamonds worth 900 gp, which the spell consumes

spell.name: Pilfer
entries: {@i To the merchant, it was nothing more than a few missing trinkets. To Tinybones, it was the greatest heist of all time.}

You target a creature within range, uttering words of power with your hands in your pockets. If the spell is succesful, you will gain awareness of the items the target is carrying, and may swap your worthless piece of junk with one of those items. Items being worn are not affected by this spell.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the number of items you can steal increases by one.

components.m: a worthless piece of junk of your choice

spell.name: Rebuke the Rotten

entries: {@i The friars of the Militia of Saint Flamur are able to reflect their own fears in the minds of those they deem heretics, making them feel an urge to be expiated upon attacking the holy workers.}
The friars of the Militia of Saint Flamur are able to reflect their own fears in the minds of those they deem heretics, making them feel an urge to be expiated upon attacking the holy workers.

You choose a creature you can see within range and bathe it with a faint beam of divine light that falls downwards upon it. Until the spell ends, whenever the creature makes an attack roll against you or your allies, it must make a Wisdom saving throw, taking {@damage 2d6} psychic damage on a failed save, as it is filled by thoughts of sin upon performing the action.

spell.name: Hatred Spilled
entries: You look at a creature, memorising their face and close your eyes to recall upon every deed they have ever done ( To your knowledge ), the pain caused to you by them swelling up in your soul and leaking out of your eyes as pure vengeful energy, afflicting that target.

During this spells duration, you can use your bonus action to manifest your hatred and cause harm to the creature you looked upon, they must make a Wisdom saving throw, or take {@damage 2d8} necrotic damage, taking an additional {@dice d8} if they have caused you great personal pain, such as killing a loved one. This bonus is given with the DM's final discretion.
If the creature is knocked to zero hit points, the spell ends.

components.m: A beloved object that was broken by who you hate, or a shard of stained glass.

spell.name: Vow of Soul Transfusion
entries: This hour long ritual binds the soul of one willing creature with a weapon they hold in their hearts, done by creating an intricate arcane circle and fueling the mana through infused candles. The hour is spent reciting a vow to the weapon, promising to never part ways with them, to always respect them, and to give them a name of their own. They also witness a vision of the weapons history, its victories, losses and all they were used to accomplish.
The Soul Transfused weapon is considered a magic item, if it wasn't before, and can be anything the willing creature is proficient with.

After the ritual is complete, the weapon is not only linked to the willing creatures soul, but contains a piece of it inside, growing along its wielder. It receives the following benefits as the wielder levels  up:
"entries": [
You touch a creature and bestow upon it a magical enhancement. Choose one of the following effects; the target gains that effect until the spell ends.

entries.name: 3rd Level
entries: The weapon's rarity is Uncommon, it can be called to its wielders hand by calling its name, no matter how far away it is, as long as the wielder has a free hand.

entries.name: 7th Level
entries: The weapon's rarity is Rare, gaining a +1 to attack and damage rolls. You learn to control this weapon using only your shared will, requiring no hands to wield it.

entries.name: 12th level
entries: The weapon's rarity is Very Rare, gaining a +2 to attack and damage rolls. Your bond has grown so close that if you die, your soul transfers itself to be fully contained by the item, turning them into an awakened weapon. While in this awakened weapon state, your body is unstable, meaning that the weapon may be destroyed if enough damage is dealt..

entries.name: 18th Level
entries: The weapon's rarity is Legendary, gaining a +3 to attack and damage rolls. This weapon has truly become one with you, you may use a free action to attack once with it after dealing damage to one target, and when you have a critical hit wielding it you may choose to deal triple the attack damage or to fuel your weapon further, gaining a +2 to your attack and damage rolls on your next turn.

m.text: A weapon to be bonded with, 300 GP worth of precious Arcane Candles.

spell.name: Rob The Passion
entries: You point to a sentient creature you can see that is within range, and they are then momentarily chained by arcane binds to their neck and limbs, a last chain being formed at their chest, its end in your hand. You may pull on the chain to extract the targets most precious memories, be them of an inspiration for what they do, the moment that brought them most joy in their life or the faces of loved ones, storing them in a small crystal, turning them into a husk of themselves.

The remaining husk is still sentient and feeling, and they feel a void in their heart, this may change their alignment, warp their personality or their resolve at the players or at the GMs discretion, in case its targeted at an NPC.
This spell cannot be dispelled unless counter-spelled at casting, the only way of breaking this enchantment being to find and shatter the crystal containing ones passion.
The Crystal of Passion has 20 HP, 12 AC. has no speeds and is immune to psychic and poison damage. If broken, the creatures passions will return no matter how close or far they are to the crystal.

components.m: A small crystal, where the memory will reside.

spell.name: Glamour
entries: You have crafted upon a simple Disguise-Self spell a special disguise fit for you and only you, upon casting this spell you may change your appearance to reflect a visage of another race your size to better fit in with them.

You may don your Glamour during a ten minute ritual, but you may only have one visage attached to the spell at any given time, requiring work over a long rest and 300 gp in arcane materials to change your alternate look.
If used to disguise oneself as another person, your features mimic the target as best as you can recall their appearance, working at the DMs discretion.
A creature may actively try to see through your disguise by rolling an insight (Wisdom) check against your Spell DC.

spell.name: Phyrexian Espionage

entries: {@i Even if they’re hunting for sleeper agents, who looks twice at a bird?}

You gain the service of a fowl by compleating it. It may take the form of: a hawk, an owl, a raven, or any other tiny fowl beast. Appearing where the corpse used to be, the Phyrexian spy has the statistics of the chosen form, though it is a construct instead of a beast.
Your Phyrexian spy acts independently of you, but it always obeys your commands. In combat, it rolls its own initiative and acts on its own turn.

When the Phyrexian spy drops to 0 hit points, it disappears, leaving behind its mechanical carcass. You can also dismiss your Phyrexian spy at any time as an action, causing it to disappear. In either case, casting this spell again summons the same Phyrexian spy, restored to its hit point maximum. Additionally, as an action, you can see through your Phyrexian spy's eyes and hear what it hears until the start of your next turn, gaining the benefits of any special senses that the Phyrexian spy has. During this time, you are deaf and blind with regard to your own senses.
While your Phyrexian spy is within 1 mile of you, you can communicate with each other telepathically.
You can have more than one Phyrexian spy bonded by this spell at a time.

components.m: the corpse of a fowl and Phyrexian oil

spell.name: Lagna's Silly String
entries: {@i And just like that, anyone's plans up in ropes!}
You enchant a length of string or a similar material to obey your commands spontaneously and to fling themselves to another creature.

During the duration of this spell, you may command your string to do simple tasks such as hold or lift a small object, or wrap itself around you or another willing creature to lift them to up to 25 ft in the air, yet making it so their move speed is of 10 ft.

Additionally, you may, using an action ( Which can be the one used to cast this spell ) fling your strings onto a creature within range, they must make a Strength saving throw or take reduce a value equal to your proficiency modifier on their next attack or saving throw, as their limbs are tangled into the strings who pull back and forth in a silly chaos.

components.m: 25-ft of String or Rope, which the spell consumes.

spell.name: Puddle of Connections
entries: {@i Every druid within the Dizhén has met another through various Communions of Spirits that happen every few years, and some decide to stay in touch, not through animal messengers nor whispers in the wind, but through a gift in the waters.}

You do a ritual around a sizeable body of water, binding its essence through a second one that must have the same ritual done, using one item of importance for yourself. This bond can be made with the help of another druid using part of the same item to link both.

This enchanted body of water is able to echo any noise in its vicinity, reflect its linked partner's surface when stared at and one may place a gift no bigger than it inside, when fully submerged it will reemerge on the other side.

components.m: A body of water that is at least 15-ft wide and deep.

spell.name: Combat Research
entries: By casting this spell, you can absorb all of the strategic information of a book regarding combat, military strategies, or warfare. The creature you touch gains all of the book's information temporarily, and acquires the following traits until the spell ends:
• Your AC increases by 1;
• Whenever you miss an attack roll, you may spend a reaction to try and attack again;
• If the enemy is holding a weapon you are proficient with, you may spend a reaction to impose disadvantage on their attack rolls this turn;
• You have advantage on saving throws to resist trap effects and natural hazards, and advantage when trying to perform an action that would make those trigger on an enemy.

components.m: A combat strategy book

spell.name: Runic Shot
entries: {@i "Target acquired."}

You conjure an arcane arrow and immediately launch it at the target. They must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC or take {@damage 4d10} piercing damage, and have the arrow become stuck on their body.

At the start of each of their turns, they take {@damage 3d6} force damage unless they spend an action to yank the arcane arrow out of their wound. On a succesful save, they take half the damage and the arcane arrow does not become stuck.

spell.name: Nova's Fashion Disaster
entries: {@i "I am SO sorry, but these are still prototypes, not on stock! So no, you CAN'T have them! You can have this, though!."}

You start channeling magic into your needle, whirring it around a small mannequin to resemble the armor or clothes the target is wearing, you then scramble everything to give it new shape, changing the target in the proccess!
They must pass a Charisma saving throw, or suffer one of the following effects, of which you choose:
• The targets AC bonus from the armor becomes a negative, as an example, a creature wearing leather armor with a +2 to dexterity would instead have this bonus turned into a -2 until your next turn.
• The target suffers a negative modifier to any charisma rolls equal to your spellcasting modifier until your next turn.

components.m: Weavers Tools & a Tiny Mannequin

spell.name: Citizen's Arrest

time.condition: which you take when a Phyrexian sleeper agent reveals itself

entries: {@i “What lurks behind the faces of those you think you can trust?” }

Once a Phyrexian sleeper agent within 30 feet of you reveals itself, you may force them to make a Dexterity saving throw; they make this saving throw with disadvantage. If they fail, you wrap them with magically infused wires able to hold them down. They are considered {@condition restrained} for the duration of the spell, and may attempt the saving throw again at the end of each of their turns, still with disadvantage.
For the duration of the spell, {@condition restrained} Phyrexians take {@damage 1d12} radiant damage on the start of their turns, as the arcana-seeped wires melts into their flesh and steel.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you can choose between increasing the amount of creatures you can target by one, or increasing the radiant damage by {@dice 1d12} for each slot level above 2nd.

components.m: A piece of Phyrexian wire or circuitry

spell.name: Impede Momentum

time.condition: which you take when a creature moves

entries: You imbue a character with lethargic thoughts, as blue arcane energy seeps into their body.

Once a creature within 30 feet of you attempts to start a movement action, you may immediately force it to roll a Wisdom saving throw. If it fails, it will only be able to move up to half of its movement speed.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, you can increase its range by 30 feet.

spell.name: Agressive Sabotage
entries: {@i "Squee’s orders basically came down to “attack the squishy parts.”}

You touch a piece of non-sentient technology, and disrupt its functioning. Until the spell ends, the object will not work properly, and you get to choose how it breaks. If it's a camera, it could simply stop working, or it could show a different image. If it's a door, it could stay locked for the remainder of the time, it could stay open, or it could open and close at random intervals. Your DM is the ultimate arbiter to decide what does and doesn't work for a certain object.
If the piece of technology you're trying to disrupt is magical, roll your spell attack modifier against the object's DC. The object's DC is equal to 15 + 2 for each rarity level above Common.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the amount of time the device stays malfunctioning for increases by 20 minutes.

components.m: pieces of broken gears

spell.name: Choking Miasma
entries: The Phyrexians were as surprised as anyone to discover they still needed to breathe.

You create a 20-foot-radius sphere of poisonous, yellow-green miasma centered on a point you choose within range. The miasma spreads around corners. It lasts for the duration or until strong wind disperses the miasma, ending the spell. Its area is heavily obscured.

When a creature enters the spell's area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, that creature must make a Constitution saving throw. The creature takes {@damage 3d10} force damage on a failed save, and a point of Exhaustion; on the next round, if they're still within the miasma and fail the saving throw again, they will take the damage and choke, becoming {@condition unconscious}. If they receive damage or the miasma disperses, they will immediately awake and this spell's process will start again if the miasma is still present. On a successful save, they take half as much damage and none of the other effects. Creatures are affected even if they hold their breath or don't need to breathe.

The miasma moves 10 feet away from you at the start of each of your turns, rolling along the surface of the ground. The vapors, being heavier than air, sink to the lowest level of the land, even pouring down openings.

components.m: A dried up mushroom.

spell.name: Ghoul Rose
entries: You throw a black rose charged with necrotic energy at a target within 60 feet. The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or  the rose embeds itself in their skin and a thread of energy binds the rose to you.

At the start of each of the target's turns, they take {@damage 2d4} necrotic damage, and you heal for half that amount (rounded up). You can choose to give the other half of the healed amount to a creature within 5 feet of you.
At the end of each of the target's turns, they can repeat the Dexterity saving throw. On a success, the spell ends.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4nd level or higher, the healing increases by {@dice 4d4} for each slot level above 1st.

components.m: A withered rose petal.

spell.name: Corpse Flower
entries: You concentrate life and death energy into a flower planted in the ground. The flower grows until it is as big as a person, becoming a Corpse-Flower with AC 10, 100 hit points and immunity to necrotic and poison damage, but vulnerability to fire damage.

At the end of each day, an undead creature emerges from the plant, under your control. You can control one of the undead, and it will under your control for 24 hours, after which they become free-willed.

The flower gives off a strong scent of decay that can be smelt within 30 feet, and any creature that ends its turn within 10 feet of the Corpse-Flower takes {@damage 2d4} poison damage. If a creature dies from this poison damage, it becomes an undead.
Any undead created by this flower, whether dying or emerging, is defined the following table:
Even if you have created more than one corpse flower created you will still only be able to choose a single undead.

components.m: a flower planted at the casting site

entries.name: Age
entries: A halfling reaches adulthood at the age of 20 and the rest of their years depend on the folk they've adapted to.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: The Chamur nomadic nature tends to cause them to usually remain neutral towards most situations, and altough fierce with the traditions they've learnt, they do not nescessarily lean towards lawfulness.

entries.name: Size
entries: Halflings average about 3 feet tall and weigh about 40 pounds. Your size is usually Small, but may differ from that and become Medium depending on who you've adapted to.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 25 feet.

entries.name: Lucky
entries: When you roll a 1 on an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll.

entries.name: Brave
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being frightened.

entries.name: Knowledge Absorbed
entries: You have picked up on the culture of whatever folk you've grown around. You can take a language that kind of folk would learn, such as learning giant from Goliaths or auran from an Air Genasi, in addition to that, you may also gain one fititng tool or skill proficiency that said folk learns, such as Dwarve's Tool Proficiency or even a set of weapon proficiencies, like the Wood Elf's Elven training.

entries.name: Welcoming Soul
entries: As a Half-Soul halfling, your body tends to adapt to whatever culture you've grown up around and the primary amount of folk you spent time with. You gain one ability from this list according to what folk you've grown around. Your appearence also takes after the common physical traits of those folk, such as being shorter and having bears when around dwarves, long pointy ears and finer features with elves, or even a hairy body and gangly limbs when around bugbears! ( This table takes in account mainly Mordekainen Presents Monsters of the Multiverse. )

entries.caption: Welcoming Soul Table
rows: Eerie Token {Choose between Telepathic Message or Remote Viewing} [VRGR]
Shifting { Die reduced to D4, Walking speed to 5. }
Feline Agility { Add only half of speed }

entries.name: Age
entries: The Dormice have the possibility to live a few dozens of years longer than humans, yet because of heavy labour thorought their lives its hard to see one make it so far past their 60s. They mature at the same rate as humans.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Akin to most Dormice, you might have an inherent rebelliousness to you, having grown up facing harsh stereotypes of your kin and the mockery that came with it, such expectations making you usually put yourself and your own first, leaning toward Neutrality. Now, if you supress your inner revolt and keep your chin up to uphold the laws you found yourself surrounded by or lash out in pure chaos, is up to you.

entries.name: Crafty Little Things
entries: In the end, yes, you've dabbled in one trade or another. You gain one skill proficiency of your choice and proficiency in one tool of your choice.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of yourself as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You discern colors in that darkness only as shades of gray.

entries.name: Keen Ears
entries: You possess large ears that can pick up even the smallest noises, gaining proficiency in the Perception skill.

entries.name: Language
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and halfling.

entries.name: Inner Rebellion
entries: Sometimes, enough is enough! Like a magical flame coursing through your veins, when it all comes to a stopping point you can channel your rage to deepen  your focus! You have a pool of Rebellion Tokens, its maximum amount equals your proficiency modifier and you can hold no number higher than it. You regain a token every time you've suffered a ( Cumulative ) third of your maximum HP in a battle or you critically fail a check, and can use them to add 1d4 to an ability check or saving throw, you can do that after you've rolleed, but before the DM determines the result.

entries.name: Age
entries: Starborn have very long lifespans, and are technically immortal as long as they aren't killed. They live around 1000 to 2000 years until evolving to the next stage of their lives.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Starborn are guided by their own instincts and the beliefs around them that they wish to pick up on. You're usually Neutral, but may pend to any alignment you see as benefitial to you.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of yourself as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You discern colors in that darkness only as shades of gray.

entries.name: Cold Resistance
entries: You were accustomed to the frigid depths of space, and therefore is resistant to cold damage.

entries.name: Horoscope
entries: Once per day, you may look at the stars, if they're visible, and attempt to discern things yet to come. Roll a d100, and make yourself a question regarding a future event. The closer the number is to 100, the clearer and more accurate the answer is.

entries.name: Natural Camouflage
entries: Because of your darker skin, you are considered invisible to the enemy when covered in shadows. When hidden like this, you may will the stars on your body to burn bright. Choose a creature within 10 ft. of you, they must make a Constitution saving throw against a DC equal to 10 + your CHA modifier + your CON modifier, if they fail, they become blinded until the end of their next turn.
You may use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency modifier, and you regain all expanded uses after a short or long rest.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Celestial, or one other language that you and your DM agree is appropriate for your character.

entries.name: Age
entries: The Chamur are considered adults when they turn 200 years old, and go on to live indefinitely.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: The Chamur nomadic nature tends to cause them to usually remain neutral towards most situations, and altough fierce with their tradition, they do not nescessarily lean towards lawfulness.

entries.name: Size
entries: The Chamur are commonly built like lanky humans. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Arcane Vision
entries: You know the {@spell detect magic|PHB} spell.

entries.name: Environmental Adaptability
entries: You gain resistance to one damage type and one cantrip based on the region you currently find yourself in, your appearance also changes accordingly.

entries.caption: Environmental Adaptability Table
rows: Your skin and scales turn pale and your eyes an icy blue.
Your skin and scales turn the color of sand, your hands become akin to an amphibians.
Your skin and scales turn red and your eyes black, your scales rise as obsidian spikes.
Your skin and scales turn a light grey, the sole of your feet harden and your scales sway to the wind.
Your skin and scales turn a greenish yellow with some blots, your hands gain amphibious characteristics and your scales become thicker.
Your skin and scales turn as black as night and your eyes a shiny white, your scales become soft and slimy.
Your skin turns an oakish brown and your scales become hard as wood, colored akin to a chameleon.
Choose between slashing, piercing or bludgeoning.

entries.name: Metapanoplís
entries: When you reach third level, you may use your reaction to choose a creature that has attacked you. You gain resistance to all attacks made by that creature for the next 24 hours. You may only use this trait once a day.

entries.name: Language
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one language of your choice.

Ah, the Chamur? Curious families, I'm not quite sure where they're from, but that shouldn't be the question asked, not when you ask it expecting a normal answer. These people, the Chamur, they truly are from everywhere.

The Chamur are various nomadic reptilian people. Due to their longevity, being able to live indefinitely, their reproduction cycle is low, generating a small amount of children that take a long time to grow up into adulthood and even longer to detach from their parents.

entries.name: People of Nowhere and Everywhere
entries: Because of both rarity the Chamur have developed a natural capacity to adapt to any kind of place at a moments notice, gaining new benefactory traits depending on the locale they find themselves in.

Due to their natural adaptability they get along well with humans and half-elves. The majority of Chamur make their lifes as traders, selling various items from far-lands they have visited. It is not rare for them to sell exquisite and rare magic items.

entries.name: Tradition in Blood
entries: They generally roam in families of up to five people, with a leader chosen by the majority, and when the children turn into adults they peregrinate in search of another Chamur to create a new family.
When a member of a Chamur family is harmed or prejudiced, the family as a whole will stop at nothing to get their revenge, as grave as it may be. They tend to hold grudges as long as their own lifes.

Chamurs generally hate intolerance, and at the same time they tend to be progressive in their methods, they carry a cultural traditionalism with them, trying to perfect themselves without forgetting their past.

entries.name: Knack for the Arcane
entries: The Chamur are widely known as traders of magical wonders and highly perceptive as to the nature of magic items in general, although many rumours are spread around as to why, such as thinking its a celestial boon from a deity or a tightly sealed secret passed down from generation to generation, in truth that is because of their natural affinity to seeing the magic of the world with naked eyes.

entries.name: Chamur amongst other races
entries: Althrough nomadic, some rare times Chamur families settle down into another races society, or even rarer, a single Chamur breaks off from their family to settle down or walk amongst others far from their kind.
When in another society, they tend to make competent politicians, alchemists, traders, druids and diplomats.

entries.name: Chamur Adventurers
entries: To the Chamur, adventure is a vital part of their life cycle, be it the more usual time when they splinter from their families at adulthood to search for a mate for life, acquiring rare magic items for trade or in very rare cases, a Chamur who has left their family in pursuit of an adventure truly of their own making.

Most other races might see the Chamur as weird and mysterious, yet the common sight about them is that they are a wise and knowledgeable people, tied down to bone with their ancestry, but with an eye for treasure like no other.

entries.name: Chamur Names
entries: Chamur names usually are either based off on their ancestors or from the places their family has visited through their lifetimes.

entries.name: Bonds of Steel
entries: Created as the result of a father and his son's love for life and creation, forgekins are somewhat of a recent stroke on Aster's canvas. Built of metal chassis, with a mana-enriched core to sustain vital function, they bear on their arms the teachings of Hugo, The Father, living a life based on self-discovery and protection of all that is good. Forging a bond with a forgekin is having a silly - but somehow wise friend - for life and beyond.

entries.name: Age
entries: Being created based on Hugo's physiology, with only a few add-ons (such as the ability to shed tears and feel taste), forgekins are unable to physically age. You are immune to magical aging effects.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Following Hugo's tenets, forgekins are usually neutral or lawful good creatures, with a tendency for caring dearly for life and the living. However, as it was intended that each individual took hold of their own life, there's always a chance for them to drift away from the path. Even their father had lost his confidence at some point, after all.

entries.name: Size
entries: Hugo sure had lots of fun when designing each of their bodies. As a forgekin, you can be tall, short, skinny, round, have a head shaped like an oblong, you name it. they do tend to be heavy though. It comes with the whole 'my body is made of some of the most wear-resistant alloys known to men' thing.
You can choose to be of either small or medium size.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Runic.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color properly in darkness, with them meshing into one another.

entries.name: Constructed Resilience
entries: You were created to have remarkable fortitude, represented by the following benefits:
You have advantage on saving throws against being poisoned, and you have resistance to poison damage.

items: You don’t need to eat, drink, or breathe.
You are immune to disease.
You don't need to sleep, and magic can't put you to sleep.

entries.name: Sentry's Rest
entries: When you take a long rest, you must spend at least six hours in an inactive, motionless state, rather than sleeping. In this state, you appear inert, but it doesn’t render you unconscious, and you can see and hear as normal.

entries.name: Integrated Protection
entries: Your body has built-in defensive layers, which can be enhanced with armor.
You gain a +1 bonus to Armor Class..

entries.name: Specialized Design
entries: Hugo made each forgekin slightly different from the others, both on their appearance and their cores. The result is a myriad of minor gifts, only discovered after their awakening. Choose one of the following abilities:

items: You gain one extra Skill and Tool proficiency;
Once per long rest, you can choose to cast a spell with more potency. If you do so, your spell has their effects upcasted to the next level, while still spending its usual spell slot ;
You inherently know 1 cantrip from the Wizard's Spell list. Intelligence is your casting modifier for this spell.

Choose one of the following spells: {@spell Absorb elements}, {@spell Thunderwave} and {@spell Detect Magic}. Once per Long rest, you can cast this spell on its lowest level without spending a spell slot. Intelligence is your casting modifier for this spell.

entries.name: Age
entries: Dominarian Viashinos reach maturity around age 14 and rarely live longer than 60 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Dominarian Viashinos tend to be Chaotic, pending towards all kinds of forces of good, evil, and even neutrality, as long as they're not restrained by any laws or stiff ideologies.

entries.name: Size
entries: Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet and you have climbing speed equal to your walking speed..

entries.name: Slender Frame
entries: You are used to running, and quickly setting up and taking down their camps whenever necessary. Whenever you take the Dash action, you triple your walking speed instead of doubling it..

entries.name: Ever Unafraid
entries: You have resistance on saving throws against being frightened. Furthermore, you have resistance from damage dealt by all dragons.

entries.name: Drakespeaker
entries: Draconic blood flows in your veins, magically empowering you. You may attempt to control a dragon's actions during your turn, forcing them to do something you command, provided they
are within 30 feet of you and you can see them. You may issue them any order, as long as it doesn't directly or indirectly cause them harm. You may do this a number of times equal to
your Charisma modifier, and regain all expended uses on a long rest.

entries.name: Language
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Draconic, or one other language that you and your DM agree is appropriate for your character.

In Dominaria, viashino are the main civilization on the Shivan sands. In addition to Shiv, they may be found throughout the Burning Isles and as far west as Jamuraa. The viashino live in clan communities,

each of which is led by a ''bey'', and have a society of warriors. They live almost exclusively in simple desert camps, which can disappear in minutes if they decide to mobilize. Despite the emphasis on

militarism and their warrior code, the viashino are also known for their metalsmithing and crafts. As harsh as the desert is, the viashino are suited to it, relying on ”sandswimming” for transportation and
tactical advantage.
Viashino have constantly been skirmishing with the Goblins, which are also native to Shiv, the Ghitu tribe of humans, and even the Shivan dragons themselves. In the face of any outside adversity, the
viashino often became staunch allies of the goblins and the Ghitu. The four species now have formed the Shivan Nation together.

The Viashino of Tamingazin live in the city of Berimish. The city does not have any stairs, as they prefer to use climbing poles. Older viashino “retire to the breeding house” and they don't know their ”gender” until they reach maturity.
A cold-blooded species, the viashino survived the Ice Age by hiding within the Mana Rig.

entries.name: Accursed Murmurs
entries: You know the {@spell Calamity|CS} cantrip.

entries.name: Abominable Heritage
entries: The ancient cursed blood that runs in your veins has taken the impulses of fear and numbed them, enabling you advantage against being frightened. Besides, you have also gained better control of your impulses, gaining advantage against being moved against your will as long as the movement's source is of a magical nature.

entries.name: Age
entries: Sipheans tend to live around 80 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Sipheans normally gravitate towards lawfulness because of their tendency to abide by law and their communities' well-being, be it good or evil.

entries.name: Size
entries: You are Medium or Small. You choose the size when you select this race.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

entries.name: Low Burn, Endless Burn
entries: You are used to failure and the frustration it always brings along, but you have learnt how to use it to keep you fueled to move on. Whenever you fail an ability check or saving throw, you may choose to grant a bonus to your next roll equal to the amount of failures leading up to it ( Ex: If you have failed twice, you gain a +2 ),  that bonus cannot exceed your proficiency modifier. This bonus can only be used in ability checks, saving throws and attacks.

entries.name: Language
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one language of your choice.

{@i Sit down, kid. 'Tis time to finally answer whar you wanted... Why are we like this. In times even older than me, I know, hard 'ta believe, our ancestors made a silly, stupid, joke with the God of creativity. The God... Didn't like it, not one bit. Can't blame 'im, I hate jokes like that too. He cursed us, thats why we have these pretty horns, the hooves and... The hands. Y'kno kid, our life is hard, but it always gets better. Seeing you now makes me hopeful for the future, you'll do well, I 'noe you will.}

The Siphean are a race of humanoids with caprine qualities, such as heads resembling goats with horns and slit-pupils in their eyes, behooved legs and either short tails or long, leathery tails with a pointed tip, akin to a devils.

entries.name: The Well of Frustration
entries: A long, long time ago, the Sipheans were once members of another existing race, the specific one lost to time itself. That was until a group of them decided to play a prank on the god of creativity, a prank so large it upset the deity, which in turn, cursed their bloodlines until they could fulfill a special condition.

This curse left them with changed bodies, the one we know today, but whats most was taking their ability to master arts and crafts, be them magical or scientific, forced to live in perpetual mediocrity. They but one hope, an unreachable one at their state, the one condition to break their curse, to play a song that would make the Gods weep.

When a member of a Chamur family is harmed or prejudiced, the family as a whole will stop at nothing to get their revenge, as grave as it may be. They tend to hold grudges as long as their own lifes.

Chamurs generally hate intolerance, and at the same time they tend to be progressive in their methods, they carry a cultural traditionalism with them, trying to perfect themselves without forgetting their past.

entries.name: Weird Little Guys
entries: What differentiates yordles from other magical folk is that their physiology is more consistent between its members.

Yordles are sometimes sexually dimorphic and much shorter than humans; both sexes rarely exceed 1 meter tall, with most averaging between 0.5 and 0.8 meters. Their skin texture ranges from being lightly covered in fur, to moderately fuzzy, to ultimately being excessively bushy. Their hands have four digits while their feet differ greatly depending on the individual (from four to two digit feet). Their fur tones run a much broader spectrum of colors than their human counterparts; some consider this to be a sign of the yordles’ attunement to Runeterra's magical nature; though scientists agree that this evolutionary trait is used by male Yordles (which tend to be have more fur and a somewhat bestial appearance) to attract females of their species (which tend to be lightly covered with fur and much more human looking). Their large eyes feature a large, circular iris with a vertically oval pupil, and they generally have inferior vision in the normal spectrum of light than humans. Yordles nevertheless have much better hearing, due to their large fox-like ears and are able to see into the infrared spectrum of light, whereas humans cannot. Furthermore, they are commonly characterized by their dependence on language, as well as their creation and utilization of complex tools.

entries.name: A Culture of All
entries: Yordle culture is gregarious and varied; they require far more social interaction than humans do. They generally are a peaceful and amicable race, often marked with streaks of joviality and light prankishness, with their personality most often pointed toward benevolence. Their desire for social interaction also drives them toward this ethos, as the mental health of a yordle is very much dependent on the positive company he or she keeps.
This race has multiple subraces, as listed below:
{@race Yordle (Ancient-Blood)|CompendiumSecreto}
{@race Yordle  (Manaspark)|CompendiumSecreto}
{@race Yordle  (Glamourous)|CompendiumSecreto}

entries.name: Age
entries: The Yordle have a different view on age itself because of their magical ancestry, although they reach maturity at the same speed of a human, they do not die from old age, possessing the rare ability to outlive even elves, provided they aren’t hunted down before they can do so.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Yordles in their vast majority are very social races, and in most cases tend to lean into Good ideals, being a generally peaceful and amicable race, even though they might have streaks of joviality or a little prankishness. Most specific ideals a Yordle has come from the society they surround themselves with, adopting beliefs and feelings easily from their surroundings, which makes them susceptible to absorbing Evil traits either by being surrounded by other evil-doers or deprived of others, making them crave for societal interactions in more desperate manners.

entries.name: Size
entries: Yordles average about 2,25 feet tall and weigh about 40 pounds. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Keen Ears
entries: You possess large ears that can pick up even the smallest noises, gaining advantage on perception checks related to sound..

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and either Bandle or  one other language of your choice.

entries.name: Subrace
entries: The Yordle, due to their different approaches to life, have a plethera of very different sub-races. Choose one of them.

entries.name: Yordle Magic
entries: You are a spirit of essentially pure magic manifested, and as such, you may manifest it in some special way. You learn one cantrip and one 1st level spell from the Wizards spell list, and may cast it once per day. You regain the ability to use it at dawn.

entries.name: Air bubble
entries: You can create a bubble filled with oxygen so that a creature may accompany you in the depths. The creature can wear the bubble as a helmet, nose implement, or however they see fit. They are able to breathe for 1 hour until the bubble pops. After you assist in the casting of the spell, you can't use this feature again until you complete a long rest. You can create a bubble of air a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Age
entries: Merfolks of Dominaria reach adulthood in their late teens and live less than a century.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Merfolks of Dominaria are usually Lawful Neutral, following the laws left behind by their ancestors and attempting to protect the flow of magic that infuses their world's oceans.

entries.name: Size
entries: You have the average height of a human, your size is medium.

entries.name: Knowledge of the Deep
entries: If you or a caster you know attempts to cast a spell, you can use your reaction to make it so the spell is cast using a spell slot of a lower level, up to at least 1st-level. After you assist in the casting of the spell, you can't use this feature again until you complete a long rest.

entries.name: Water Manipulation
entries: You know the Shape Water cantrip. Starting at 7th level, you can cast the Control Water spell with this trait. Once you cast Control Water with this trait, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a long rest. You can also cast that spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells when you cast them with this trait (choose when you select this race)

type.name: Language
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Aquan.

entries.name: Age
entries: Yavimayan Apes tend to live until they're 35 to 40 years old. They reach adolescence at the age of 5 and adulthood at the age of 10.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Yavimayan Apes are usually Lawful Neutral, following the commands of their elders, of Yavimaya and of Multani.

entries.name: Enlist
entries: Whenever you are Helped, you roll an additional damage dice for your weapon equal to twice the number of helpers.

entries.name: Siege Monster
entries: You deal double damage to objects and structures.

entries.name: Strong Muscles
entries: You have a climbing speed equal to your walking speed. Additionally, you have proficiency in either Athletics or Acrobatics (your choice), and advantage when making any checks requiring you to climb or hold on to surfaces.

type.name: Language
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and any other language of your choice..

entries.name: Fuzzy Little Guys
entries: The Ancient yordles posses a much more bestial appearance, with thick fur and sharp canines, holding the whole races roots in their bloodstreams, normally staying away from  the notion of advanced technology, instead using the magic latent in their self to grow into large beasts, turning the table on any hunter who makes the mistake of thinking they’re prey. They tend to be more prideful than their cousins, if an Ancient-blood Yordle perceives anyone belittling them, be it in an intentional or not they get quite furious.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Most ancient-blood Yordles live and die by their own judgements, finding annoyance in following any laws set upon them or in some cases refusing it outright, making them bend to the Chaotic aspects of life.

entries.name: Feral Pursuit
entries: Your shorter stature never leaves you in a bad situation when it comes to moving, by using a bonus action on your turn you may stash or drop whatever you are holding and start to run on all fours, gaining an extra 15 ft. of movement and ignoring the first 10 ft. of difficult terrain.

entries.name: Rush of the Ancients
entries: You are deeply connected to the roots of your kind, way before when Yordles were still tribal, without technology to aid you. Once per day, you can choose to enter a state of synchronicity with your lineage. During this state, you gain the following abilities.

items: You can use your claws to make unarmed strikes. When you hit with them, the strike deals 1d4 + your Strength modifier slashing damage, instead of the bludgeoning damage..
Your strength increases by +2.

You grow one size larger, if any enemy is within the range of your growth they must make a strength ( athletics ) saving throw against your a DC equal to your 10+ strength modifier + proficiency bonus., or be pushed 5 ft. back, to an empty space.

entries.name: Age
entries: A typical warforged is between two and thirty years old. The maximum lifespan of the warforged remains a mystery; so far, warforged have shown no signs of deterioration due to age.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Most warforged take comfort in order and discipline, tending toward law and neutrality, but some have absorbed the morality—or lack thereof—of the beings they served with.

entries.name: Miner's Collapse
entries: You may use this ability an amount of times equal to your proficiency modifier, and regain its use after a short or long rest.

entries.name: Warforged Resilience
entries: You were created to have remarkable fortitude, represented by the following benefits:

items: You are immune to disease.
You don't need to eat, drink, or breathe.
You don't need to sleep and don't suffer the effects of exhaustion due to lack of rest, and magic can't put you to sleep.

entries.name: Sentry's Rest
entries: When you take a long rest, you must spend at least six hours of it in an inactive, motionless state, rather than sleeping. In this state, you appear inert, but it doesn't render you unconscious, and you can see and hear as normal.

entries.name: Integrated Protection
entries: Your body has built-in protective layers, which determine your Armor Class. You gain no benefit from wearing armor, but if you are using a shield, you apply its bonus as normal. You can alter your body to enter different defensive modes; each time you finish a long rest, choose one mode to adopt from the Integrated Protection table, provided you meet the mode's prerequisite.

entries.name: Mind's Eye
entries: You were once used as a machine of labor and surveillance, and although you are now at least a semi-sentient being, your abilities are still intact. You and a willing creature may spend a short rest to attune to one another, while attuned, you both are able to speak telepathically, automatically understanding each others words if both can speak at least one language, x the both of you can also, as an action, see through each other's eyes and hear what the other hears until the start of your next turn, gaining the benefits of any special senses that the other has. During this time, you are deaf and blind with regard to your own senses. You may attune to only one creature at any given time, and the attunement breaks only when you choose to. This attunement does not count toward your attunement maximum. Your connection breaks if you both are 300 feet apart.

entries.name: Nerdy Little Guys
entries: Manaspark Yordles are the most inquisitive of them all, their natural magic and wanderlust easily driving them out of Bandle City and out into the material plane, they’re not necessarily inventors, but artists of some sort, be it through simple writings and texts or by more physical or magical means, wanting to express themselves above all.the Manaspark often find themselves as a cultural centrifuge, creating unique creations that are a mishmash of their surroundings, sprung to life in a spark of inspiration.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: The Manaspark Yordles tend to always follow some sort of pattern, be it in the form of a set of methodical daily tasks or following the instructions in a project, so they do lean toward Lawfulness. In rare cases, their spark might burn far brighter than others, aiming to bend the rules a little more to reach a greater outcome.

entries: Yordles average about 2,25 feet tall and weigh about 40 pounds. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Keen Ears
entries: You possess large ears that can pick up even the smallest noises, gaining advantage on perception checks related to sound..

entries.name: Habitual Fidget
entries: You are inclined for a creative outlet everyday in some manner of crafting, on a long rest you may create a Manatech Spark, a little gadget, gizmo or totem containing a piece of your Yordle Magic. It acts as a spell scroll of a spell you know and whose level is equal to or lesser than half your current level.  It can be used by another creature and loses its properties after your next long rest. You may only have one Manatech Spark at a time.

entries.name: Manaspark-Manatech
entries: Along with your creative outbursts and disperse bouts of craftsmanship, there's still one gizmo that you always took a special liking to, keeping it with your person at all times. When you select this race, you may take an Artificer Infusion that is available at 1st level.

You may have this gadget take the form of anything that is in the general category of its prerequisite, such as a Mind Sharpener being a bonnet or glasses, or taking the Repeating Shot infusion by creating a special modification to a ranged weapon. You cannot change the Artificer Infusion taken, but you can remove the infusion from an item and into another.

entries.name: Fabulous Little Guys
entries: The Glamorous Yordles are the most sociable of all their kind, developing a spell to better fit them within wherever they may find themselves. Naturally, they have evolved to have much less fur than their peers, along with four-digits in each hand and foot.
They are also the most culturally varied of Yordles, most having left Bandle City generations ago and integrating into Asters many societies, acquiring their beliefs, morals and traits.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Glamorous Yordles take in much more of their surroundings, various cultures and beliefs, letting most of them stand in Neutral ground towards what they believe and follow.

entries.name: Size
entries: Yordles average about 2,25 feet tall and weigh about 40 pounds. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Keen Ears
entries: You possess large ears that can pick up even the smallest noises, gaining advantage on perception checks related to sound..

entries.name: Fabulous Gift
entries: You’re always ready to dress and impress! After rolling for a social interaction using any Charisma skills or to handle an animal, you may swiftly produce an uncannily fitting gift for the situation! The gift may be any kind of tiny object with a negligible price and use, still able to produce small effects like a smell or a small image, or, to the most silvered tongues, a verbal gift, stringing words and charm in a fabulous way! After rolling a check, you may choose to add 1d4 to the result, possibly turning it into a success! You may do this an amount of times equal to your proficiency modifier, restoring uses at a long rest.

entries.name: Glamour
entries: As one of the most sociable Yordles, your magic has morphed in a way befitting that! You gain the 1st level spell Glamour, your alternate appearance resembling your current as if it were in another humanoid race. If you do not have a Spell saving throw DC, you may choose to use your Wisdom, Charisma or Intelligence modifier + 10 + your proficiency bonus.

The Kynbolds are very distant cousins to the Kobolds, adapted along centuries to the colder outside from the mountains of Ingrir, over time losing their scales as they acquired strong leathery hides and, even though short, thick furs covering almost their entire bodies.

entries.name: Ditant, Distant Cousins
entries: Centuries ago, the kobolds lived deep inside caverns inside the mountains of Ingrid, ambushing and swarming any monster and scrap of meat they found, yet they we're slowly rooted out of the caverns by some much stronger creature, forcing them to slowly come out of the caverns.

Adapting to the even colder climate, and with the blessing of Ingrir they slowly shedding their scales and growing a short, yet dense fur, only getting longer at their tails, gaining pads on the palms of their hands to help with climbing the mountains.
Yet they still retain aspects from their original race, such as the shape of their legs and their sharp teeth.

As they were rooted out from the caves, the kynbolds original selfishness and smooth brain were forced to be left in the caves, with the kynbolds evolving to work better together and striving to have the group survive, slowly forming the culture they have today.

As this went along, their unique creativity that was used only for trap-making spreaded to other areas of creation, and as their tech evolved, large groups of kynbolds even evolved to form villages ontop of the mountains, where most of the beasts from the valleys couldn't reach them.

entries.name: Caretakers of Ingrir
entries: On top of the snow-coated tops of the Ingrir mountains, and in the valleys inbetween, the Kynbolds, after centuries of adapting and learning to survive taking care of one another, eventually growing into modest villages and refuges, with parties of roaming soldiers searching the valleys below for forage and people who have fallen to the cold, so they can take care of a new potential ally.

In Kynbold society, taking the first step to stabilish the safety of the whole and being hospitable in a bad situation is seen as an honorable act and even an individual contribution benefitting the whole as an unspoken rule, as dead weights will do nothing but feed the freezing winds of Ingrir.

This makes it so anyone who helps, whatever way it be, kynbold settlements be proof that they are worthy of the hospitality shown by the caretakers of Ingrir; Their initial kindness however, has its other side of the coin, with Kynbolds easily becoming hostile when someone shows themselves as unwilling to offer help to others in times of need or be generally destructive, this being much worse when trust is broken, a burnt bridge with a Kynbold is forever-blazing, and most often, a betrayer will be hunted and punished for their deeds.

entries.name: Infused With the Frost
entries: As the kynbolds adapted and managed to survive in Ingrir, the god of Frost had seen their efforts, and rewarded them by giving some of his blood for them, imbuing the Kynbold bloodlines with innate frost magic, gaining the ability to at least partially shape ice to their will.

This also manifests physically, as kynbold blood is cyan, and some who show more prowess with their gift, with ice crystals forming around their horns and in some even rarer cases, having their entire horns being made out of a never-melting, dense ice.

entries.name: Life in sound
entries: Star genasi use the naming conventions of the people among whom they were raised. They might later assume the names of constellations or stars, such as Orion, Polaris, or Vega. Some take on more vague names to reflect their origins, such as Nebula, Nova, or Starlight.

entries.name: Kynbold Names
entries: A kynbold's proper name is chosen by themselves in accordance to a clan leader in a coming of age ceremony when they reach their 15th year of life, with them receiving a leather collar with a copper bell with their name being etched on the latter, and their name commonly being based on either the way they contribute to society, after doing something they take pride in, or rarely, in some cases after a life-long goal of theirs.

Before they choose their names, they often receive a nickname based on their physical traits, as an example, these could be based on their fur or eye colors, or even the shape and size of their horns.

entries.name: Age
entries: Kynbolds reach maturity at age 8 but are only considered adults at age 15 and can live up to 80 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: As the Kynbolds adapted to the frigid and dangerous mountains of Ingrir, they were forced to become less selfish and survive united as one. All of this culminated in them believing in strenght in numbers and that any addition to the whole is welcome as long as it proves itself as an individual, making them lean towards neutral good.

entries.name: Size
entries: Kynbolds are between 3 and 5 feet tall and weigh between 35 and 50 pounds. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and giant.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color properly in darkness, with them meshing into one another.

entries.name: Cold Resistance
entries: You have resistance to cold damage.

entries.name: Vigilant Guardian
entries: When a creature you can see within 5 feet of you is hit by an attack roll, you can use your reaction to swap places with that creature, and you are hit by the attack instead. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Blood of Ingrir.
entries: You know the {@spell sculpt ice|TalesofOleander} cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell ice knife|xge} spell as a 2nd-level spell; you must finish a long rest in order to cast the spell again using this trait. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for these spells.
See subraces.
Fuck.

Nobody is quite sure of where the goblins, or for that fact, even the other goblinoids came from, some say they are also sculptures of Atlas, brought to life like humans, others say that the goblins were the original creations of atlas, with humans being no more than one of their many evolutionary lines.
Either ways, goblins are a diverse and vast race, having many sorts of people, habits and cultures, some being integrated in others and some being near monsters.

entries.name: Adaptation at its finest
entries: If the gods gifted each race with something, the goblins' gift would certainly be their unrivaled ability to adapt to whatever surrounding they find themselves in, having many evolutionary lines that strive far from the usual green gremlin you might find lying about near towns and thieving others, such as more civilized city dwelling goblins or the reclusive stoneskin goblins.
A goblin sub-race is always distinct from another, even though they share the same ancestry.

entries.name: Many kinds, many cultures
entries: The goblins can be found near anywhere in Oleander, albino's and stoneskins' found within caverns, greenwaters in marshes and swamps along lizardfolk, city dwellers and even the more common followers about anywhere near towns and kingdoms.

Their cultures vary greatly, while a tribe of greenwater goblins might become more primal and spiritual, only hunting and foraging for food in their swamps, a city-dweller might end up developing a love for science and magic, ending up a brilliant artificer inside the greatest capitals of other races, making a true change inside.
The goblins' cultural variety is rivaled only by humans, that altough most of humanity shifts in physical changes from one another, they still spread head to head amongst one another.

entries.name: What Even Makes a Goblin?
entries: A goblin is defined by their set small height, big ears and sharp eyes, besides their more scaredy and twitchy vision of life, most even lacking in common-sense and thinking of things like magic and more advanced technology as something near impossible to understand, often times still seen fiddling with other races' magic artifacts and technology. All of those features group together all their sub-races under an unique banner of goblin.

Most races have, after centuries, grown accustomed to diferenciating the kinds of goblin, knowing followers tend to be more stupid and troublemakers, while city dwellers are easier to get along with. Still, some races, like the aarakocra prefer to keep their distance, believing that deep within, they're all tiny green troublemakers

entries.name: Goblin Names
entries: Since goblins are so adaptable and diverse, it is hard to place down a set of names commonly being sported by these small folk, still, some patterns still exist depending on their subrace

As an example, the {@race Goblin (City Dweller)|Tales of Oleander} taking up the naming conventions of the race and culture they chose to surround themselves in, or stoneskin goblins taking inspiration in dwarven names.
This race has multiple subraces, as listed below:

{@race Goblin (City Dweller)|CompendiumSecreto}
{@race Goblin (Follower)|CompendiumSecreto}
{@race Goblin (Greenwater)|CompendiumSecreto}
{@race Goblin (Stoneskin)|CompendiumSecreto}

entries.name: Age
entries: A goblin reaches adulthood at the age of 12 and rarely live more than 80 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Goblins are so variable it is hard to place their general alignment, as an example, while a Feral Goblin and an Albino Goblin are both generally chaotic creatures, Albino's are often found alone and striving to survive, while Feral goblins are often under some more powerful creature's command.

entries.name: Size
entries: Goblins average about 3 feet tall and weigh about 40 pounds. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Goblin. Most goblins who live either in more isolated places or away from proper civlization tend to speak in a more broken common, while all of them have the innate ability to speak goblin..

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color properly in darkness, with them meshing into one another.

entries.name: Subrace
entries: The goblins, due to their high adaptability, have a plethera of very different sub-races. Choose one of them.

entries.name: Squeaky
entries: You have disadvantage on saving throws against being frightened.

entries.name: Goblin Nimbleness
entries: You can move through the space of any creature that is of a size larger than yours.

entries.name: Natually Stealthy
entries: You can attempt to hide even when you are obscured only by a creature that is at least one size larger than you.

Follower goblins are the most classical of goblins, the tiny, green gremlins who tend to follow other more powerful creatures, hence the name Follower Goblins. They, individually, tend to lean towards more chaotic extremes, but most often than not, they are following the command of their master. These are the most common kind of goblins to be found, and some theorize that they are the ancestor to all other sub-races of goblin..

entries.name: Age
entries: A goblin reaches adulthood at the age of 12 and rarely live more than 80 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Goblins are so variable it is hard to place their general alignment, as an example, while a Feral Goblin and an Albino Goblin are both generally chaotic creatures, Albino's are often found alone and striving to survive, while Feral goblins are often under some more powerful creature's command.

entries.name: Size
entries: Goblins average about 3 feet tall and weigh about 40 pounds. Your size is Small.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Goblin. Most goblins who live either in more isolated places or away from proper civlization tend to speak in a more broken common, while all of them have the innate ability to speak goblin..

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color properly in darkness, with them meshing into one another.

entries.name: Ability Score Decrease
entries: Your Intelligence score decreases by 2.

entries.name: Dodgy Gremlin
entries: You are a very nimble dodger, and your innate ability to avoid being hurt at any costs gives you a base AC of 12 + your dexterity modifier.

entries.name: Paranoid
entries: You are proficient in perception checks.

entries.name: Fury of the Small
entries: When you damage a creature with an attack or a spell and the creature's size is larger than yours, you can cause the attack or spell to deal extra damage to the creature. The extra damage equals your level. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest. .

entries.name: Nimble Escape
entries: The goblin can take the Disengage or Hide action as a Bonus Action on each of its turns.

entries.name: Ability Score Increase
entries: Your dexterity increases by 2.
Fuck.

They often share personality traits with the people where they were raised, like a City Dwelling Goblin that was raised in dwarven cidatels might have picked up mining as a profession and have developed a drinking problem, or one who grew up around elves being more elegant and a bit of a prick.

entries.name: City Life
entries: You have been surrounded by other races in larger populations since you can remember, you've grown a bit taller and look a little prettier to general eyes. You are treated as a medium-size creature, standing at around 4-5 feet. You also reach maturity later than most goblins, at 18, besides that, your skin color can range from blue-ish green to yellow-ish green.

entries.name: Easy Learner
entries: As city dwelling goblins learn to fit better within their fellows, they gain both one bonus tool proficiency and a bonus skill proficiency.
Fuck.

These devilish creatures are rumoured to be the result of some wicked person throwing a bunch of slaves extremelly deep in caverns, or even Stoneskin Goblins who dwelved too deep. Albino goblins have a skin completelly devoid of melanin, barely have body hair, the most being short hairs on their heads, their body types range from skinny to just skeletal.

Their eyes have molded around darkness and have pitch black scleras with white irises and sharp, tiny pupils, their fingernails have evolved into predatory claws they use to climb walls and ambush any creature foolish enough to dwelve so deep and their teeth sharpened to devour the remains.

Due to their appearence and habits, most races see them as creepy abominations, at the best a more controlled albino goblin can be perceived as a freaky ghoul of a gobling, with most people still keeping their distance even if not aggressive.

entries.name: Adapted to the Dark
entries: You darkvision extends to 120 feet in total, and you gain blindsight with a range of 10 feet.

entries.name: Two White Dots in the Dark
entries: As a bonus action, you may hide in places obscured by shadows with advantage.

entries.name: Dark Stalkers
entries: You gain proficiency on the stealth skill.

entries.name: Cave Crawlers
entries: You are faster than your fellow goblins, gaining 35-feet of normal movement, and 25-feet of climbing speed..

entries.name: Abyssal Apparence
entries: Your charisma score decreases by 2 but you have advantage on intimidation checks and disadvantage on persuasion checks..

entries.name: Devour the flesh.
entries: You may use an action to viciously devour a dead creature to restore a number of health points equal to your level. You may only use this feature once per short rest..

entries.name: Sharp Claws
entries: You have a pair of sharp claws that count as natural weapons which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with them, you deal slashing damage equal to 1d4 + your Strength modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike..
Fuck.
The greenwater goblins are not the brightest folk around, adapted to live in the marshes and swamps of Oleander, they strive at being great hunters, having their own little tribes undwater.

They have developed the ability to shed their nose, grew small gills on the sides of their necks and special membranes between their fingers and toes. They normally have a blue-ish green pigmentation to them, and are always covered by a very thin layer of moisture. They have no body hair whatsoever.
Greenwater goblins are actually oddly friendly with sentient beings, even seeming very easygoing at times. The Greenwater tribes have been seen often befriend lizardfolk.

entries: You have developed gills and webbed fingers that let you breathe underwater and have a swimming speed of 30 ft. Besides that, this adaptation lets you move normally through muddy difficult terrain.

entries.name: King of the Marsh
entries: You have the innate ability to work with water vehicles and navigators tools, gaining proficiency with both.

entries.name: Fish Brains
entries: Your brain has evolved in a weird, unique way that ended up making it easier to think, albeit you somewhat simpler thoughs. You have advantage on wisdom saving throws.

entries.name: Greenwater Instinct
entries: You gain proficiency on the survival skill.
Fuck.

The stoneskin goblins are ones who adapted to live inside mountains, they are actually the most civilized of goblins, excluding the City Dwellers, of course, sometimes found amongst dwarves and even having come to a point of founding their own cidatel is oleander.
They take the sense of following follower goblins had and use it to create a strong hierarchy within themselves, making them lean towards lawful alignments.

They are physicially stronger than the other goblins, their body has taken a stone-like texture, with grey-ish pigmentation, with rocky protusions forming around their bodies, and their hands becoming rougher, possibilitating them to tunnel in stone. They have shorter body hair but normally sport thick eyebrows, and a pig-like nose.
